title: The MAF Method
text:
Running shouldn’t dictate your life, and you shouldn’t always be stressing about a plan. I prefer to call them schedules or guidelines.
Listen to your body. Enjoy running as part of a healthy life.

title: The MAF Method
text:
The Core Philosophy
A key feature of my training is running slow. To go fast, we must first build the engine to go far without stress.
In an ideal world, you will use a chest-strap heart rate monitor, but a wrist-based one or even “running by feel” can work if you are honest with yourself.






NoteThe 180 Formula (MAF)



The basic approach is to perform your cardio at 180 minus your age.

Example: If you are 40 years old, most of your running should be below 140 beats per minute (bpm).
The Limit: 140 bpm is the maximum, not the average.

To start with, this can be frustrating. It will likely include walking, especially uphill. I suggest a Base Phase where almost all your running is done at this heart rate. It builds a massive aerobic base without the cortisol stress of high-intensity training.

title: The MAF Method
text:
The 80/20 Rule
Another popular philosophy I use is 80/20 Running.






TipThe Balance




80% of your training should be very easy (like the MAF pace above).
20% of your training is speedwork.

Why this matters: If you run 30 miles a week and run a hard parkrun (3 miles), you have done your 10% speedwork right there. If you do the rest of your runs “kind of hard,” you are training in the grey zone—too hard to recover, too easy to get fast.


I favour a conservative approach: start at 100/0 (all easy), then move to 90/10, and finally 80/20 only when your body is ready.

title: Be Happy & Healthy
text:
First and foremost, I want you to enjoy your life. Running should be a source of happiness, not stress. My golden rule is simple: Fit running around your life, do not fit your life around your running.
Most people struggle to sustain habits that require constant discipline. Think about how hard it is to force yourself to lose weight or run in conditions you hate. If you rely on willpower alone, you will eventually burn out.
Instead, we focus on enjoyment. Prioritize your sleep, your recovery, and your family (well, assuming you enjoy your family!). When you enjoy the process, consistency happens automatically.

title: Be Happy & Healthy
text:
Prioritise Sleep
Sleep is the single most effective performance enhancer available. If you have a choice between an extra hour of sleep or setting an early alarm to squeeze in a run, choose the sleep.
Here are the key protocols I recommend for maximizing recovery:

Mind the Gap: Stop eating at least 3 hours before bed. Digestion interferes with deep sleep.
Training Timing: Try to leave a 3-hour gap between exercise and sleep. I know this is difficult with evening running clubs, but do your best to wind down.
Light Control: Use blue light filters on your devices or wear blue light blocking glasses in the evening.
Environment: Keep your bedroom cool, dark, and comfortable.
The “Light Sleeper” Hack: If you wake up easily, try sound blockers. I personally use ear buds playing an audiobook with a calm narrator. It blocks out noise and stops my brain from racing.

title: Be Happy & Healthy
text:
Integrating Family & Life
Finding time to train is often the biggest hurdle. The solution is not to ignore your family, but to integrate them into your movement.
Everything depends on your personal circumstances, but here is how I have made it work:

1. The “Social” Run
Run with a slower partner, or if you have kids, let them ride a scooter or bike alongside you while you run. You get your training done, and you get quality time together.


2. The “Errand” Run
Turn chores into training. Run to the shops, run the dog, or run to commute. It kills two birds with one stone.


3. The “Split” Run
Don’t be afraid to break a long run into bite-sized chunks.

My Experience: I have previously replaced a single long run with four mini-runs:

2 miles on the morning school run
2 miles walking the dog at lunch
2 miles on the afternoon school run
3 miles with my wife in the evening

Was a single 9-mile run better physiologically? Probably. But I couldn’t fit a continuous 90 minutes into that day. 9 miles broken up is infinitely better than 0 miles perfectly planned.

title: Personal Coaching
text:
My Philosophy
Most training plans fail because life gets in the way. A static PDF cannot adjust when you get sick, work gets stressful, or you just feel tired.
I work differently. I limit myself to a small number of runners at a time so I can provide true personalization. We will build a flexible training guide together. We remain dynamic—adjusting the structure as your life changes—so you can focus on the running while I focus on the planning.

Who I Coach
Whether your goal is getting off the couch, smashing a parkrun PB, or completing your first Half Marathon, I can help.

Important Note: I put your health first. I do not coach for distances longer than a Half Marathon (21km), as I believe the training volume required for ultra-endurance events is often contrary to long-term health.

title: Personal Coaching
text:
How It Works

1. The Onboarding
Before we run a single mile, we need to ensure we are a good match. * The Portfolio: You will complete a “Getting to Know You” portfolio covering your history, injuries, and wildest goals. * The Consultation: We will have a virtual or face-to-face meeting to dig into the details. * The Strategy: We align your target races with a realistic roadmap.


2. The Training
Humans are complex systems. Running performance is not just about miles; it is about health. * Holistic Guidance: I provide advice on strength training, mental resilience, technique, and nutrition (including low-carb/keto adaptations if that is your goal). * Regular Feedback: We stay in touch regularly. You share how you feel; I adjust the guide.

title: Personal Coaching
text:
What Is Included
When you sign up, you get a fully comprehensive package:

Initial Consultation: Deep dive into fitness, aspirations, and lifestyle constraints.
Health Audit: Review of injury history and relevant health markers.
Personalized Guide: A dynamic training structure built for you.
Feedback Loop: Regular support via email and scheduled calls.
Resource Library: Access to my advice on nutrition, mental performance, and strength conditioning.

title: Nutrition & Fasting
text:
WarningDisclaimer



I am not a qualified nutritionist. The following is based on 10 years of personal research and investigation since being obese myself. Depending on your dedication, gut health, and metabolic flexibility, there are many approaches you can take. Take from this what you want.

title: Nutrition & Fasting
text:
The Hierarchy of Diet
To start with, the priority is running slow. If you then want to ease into healthier eating, that is the next step. You don’t need to do everything at once.
Here is the progression I recommend, depending on how “strict” you want to be:

Level 1: The Basics

Remove or minimize alcohol.
Remove processed garbage (cakes, biscuits, sweets, etc.).

Level 2: The “Paleo” Approach

Reduce foods that were not available 10,000 years ago.
Cut out: Pasta, rice, flour, bread.
Eat: Meat, dairy, fruit, and vegetables.

Level 3: The Keto Diet

Remove vegetables grown below ground (potatoes, carrots, etc.).
Limit berries and high-sugar fruits.








TipGut Health



If you are struggling with digestion or inflammation, I find that Kefir really helps where other methods haven’t.

title: Nutrition & Fasting
text:
The Eating Schedule (Fasting)
“Diet” is what you eat; “Fasting” is when you eat.
This approach takes advantage of the fact that humans naturally fast overnight. Extending this window allows insulin to drop and fat cells to be mobilized. This pairs perfectly with slow running (MAF).
Work by scientists like Tim Noakes has shown that becoming “fat-adapted” increases the energy you can derive from body fat during intense exercise, significantly reducing the chance of “bonking” (running out of energy).

My Protocols

The Morning Window: Don’t eat for 2-3 hours after waking up.
Fasted Training: Do some morning runs before eating anything.

Reference: I regularly do parkrun fasted (approx. 21 hours without food).

The Evening Gap: Do not eat for at least 3 hours before bed.



Advanced Adaptation
If you take well to fat adaptation, you can push this further. It is routine for me to:

Run 10 miles first thing in the morning.
Not eat until lunchtime.
Fit in strength training or cross-training later.
Eat only one meal a day (OMAD) or within a 1-hour window.


Note: This level of fasting is for metabolically flexible runners. Don’t force it if you feel dizzy or weak.
